name: UNC2970
description: Access, evasion, and execution tactics of UNC2970

techniques.comment: UNC2970 uses phishing lures masquerading as job recruitment for prominent companies to target victims.
Victims are tricked into downloading a malicious file through WhatsApp chat.
A malicious file is delivered in a password-protected ZIP archive containing an encrypted PDF file and a modified version of an open source PDF viewer application.
The group leverages legitimate email accounts and turns SumatraPDF code into a trojanized PDF viewer to trick targets.
The threat actors pose as recruiters, modify job descriptions to better fit the targets' profiles, and target senior employees for privileged access to sensitive information.
Malicious actors use the SumatraPDF.exe executable to load malicious DLL files.
The group uses encrypted PDF files to complete tasks.
They create a scheduled task named Sumatra Launcher to execute the backdoor daily when the user logs in, ensuring persistence.
The backdoor supports various commands for different operations, including execution of received PE payloads, and process termination.
They use DLL search-order hijacking for persistence.
The backdoor also downloads and executes PE files.
MISTPEN communicates with C2 servers through HTTP.
The threat actor implements a network connectivity check that prevents the trojanized reader from displaying the decrypted PDF lure if it cannot reach google.com.
